rev.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/67.170.231.156|67.170.231.156]] ([[User talk:67.170.231.156|talk]]): "play on words" should not link to "lulz". ([[WP:TW|TW]])
rev.diff:
Line 24: Line 24:
'''GNU Hurd''' (usually referred to as '''the Hurd''') is a [[free software]] [[Unix-like]] replacement for the [[Unix]] [[kernel (computing)|kernel]],<ref name="What Is the GNU Hurd">{{cite web|url=http://www.gnu.org/software/hurd/hurd/what_is_the_gnu_hurd.html |title=What Is the GNU Hurd? |publisher=Gnu.org |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref> released under the [[GNU General Public License]]. It has been under development since 1990 by the [[GNU Project]] of the [[Free Software Foundation]]. It consists of a set of protocols and [[server (computing)|server processes]] (or [[daemon (computer software)|daemons]], in [[Unix]] terminology) that run on the [[GNU Mach]] [[microkernel]]; together they are intended to form the [[kernel (computer science)|kernel]] of the [[GNU]] operating system.<ref name="What Is the GNU Hurd"/> The Hurd aims to surpass [[Unix]] operating systems in functionality, security, and stability, while remaining largely compatible with them. The GNU Project chose the [[microkernel|microkernel serverâclient architecture]] for the operating system, due to perceived advantages over the traditional Unix [[monolithic kernel]] architecture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usenix.org/publications/login/2006-04/openpdfs/herder.pdf |title=USENIX April 06 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref>
'''GNU Hurd''' (usually referred to as '''the Hurd''') is a [[free software]] [[Unix-like]] replacement for the [[Unix]] [[kernel (computing)|kernel]],<ref name="What Is the GNU Hurd">{{cite web|url=http://www.gnu.org/software/hurd/hurd/what_is_the_gnu_hurd.html |title=What Is the GNU Hurd? |publisher=Gnu.org |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref> released under the [[GNU General Public License]]. It has been under development since 1990 by the [[GNU Project]] of the [[Free Software Foundation]]. It consists of a set of protocols and [[server (computing)|server processes]] (or [[daemon (computer software)|daemons]], in [[Unix]] terminology) that run on the [[GNU Mach]] [[microkernel]]; together they are intended to form the [[kernel (computer science)|kernel]] of the [[GNU]] operating system.<ref name="What Is the GNU Hurd"/> The Hurd aims to surpass [[Unix]] operating systems in functionality, security, and stability, while remaining largely compatible with them. The GNU Project chose the [[microkernel|microkernel serverâclient architecture]] for the operating system, due to perceived advantages over the traditional Unix [[monolithic kernel]] architecture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usenix.org/publications/login/2006-04/openpdfs/herder.pdf |title=USENIX April 06 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref>
â
''HURD'' is a [[mutual recursion|mutually]] [[recursive acronym]], standing for ''HIRD of Unix-replacing daemons'', where ''HIRD'' stands for ''HURD of interfaces representing depth''. As both ''hurd'' and ''hird'' are just alternate spellings for the English word ''herd'', the full name ''GNU Hurd'' is also a [[Lulz|play on the words]] ''[[herd]] of [[wildebeest|gnus]]'', reflecting how the kernel works.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gnu.org/software/hurd/hurd/what_is_the_gnu_hurd/origin_of_the_name.html |title=GNU Hurd: Origin of the Name |publisher=Gnu.org |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref>
+
''HURD'' is a [[mutual recursion|mutually]] [[recursive acronym]], standing for ''HIRD of Unix-replacing daemons'', where ''HIRD'' stands for ''HURD of interfaces representing depth''. As both ''hurd'' and ''hird'' are just alternate spellings for the English word ''herd'', the full name ''GNU Hurd'' is also a play on the words ''[[herd]] of [[wildebeest|gnus]]'', reflecting how the kernel works.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gnu.org/software/hurd/hurd/what_is_the_gnu_hurd/origin_of_the_name.html |title=GNU Hurd: Origin of the Name |publisher=Gnu.org |date= |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref>
